openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Argentina is the second-largest in South America, surpassed only by Brazil.
• Argentina has a human Development Index classified as "very high" by the United Nations, indicating a high standard of living and well-being.
• The country boasts a highly literate population, reflecting significant investment in education and human capital.
• Its economy features an export-oriented agricultural sector, contributing substantially to national exports.
• Argentina maintains a diversified industrial base, encompassing various manufacturing and service industries.
• The nation benefits from rich natural resources, which support various sectors of its economy.
• Historically, Argentina's economic performance has been very uneven, characterized by cycles of high growth and severe recessions, especially since the late twentieth century.
• Since the late 20th century, income maldistribution and poverty levels have increased, indicating growing economic inequality.
• In the early twentieth century, Argentina ranked among the top ten countries globally in per capita GDP, comparable to Canada and Australia, and surpassing France and Italy at that time.
• In 2018, Argentina's currency experienced a significant decline of about 50%, dropping from 18 to 20 Argentine pesos per U.S. dollar, reaching over 38 pesos per dollar.
• As of 2018, Argentina was under a stand-by program from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), indicating financial assistance and economic oversight.
• The Argentine peso continued to depreciate in 2019, falling an additional 25%.
• In 2020, the peso depreciated sharply by 90%, reflecting severe economic instability.
• In 2021, the currency depreciated by 68%, and in 2022, it fell a further 52% until July 20, highlighting ongoing currency devaluation.
• Argentina is classified as an emerging market by the FTSE Global Equity Index as of 2018, signifying its developing economic status.
• The country is recognized as one of the G-20 major economies, reflecting its significant role in global economic affairs.
• In 2021, MSCI reclassified Argentina as a standalone market due to prolonged severe capital controls, indicating restrictions on capital flows and financial market openness.
• Prior to the 1880s, Argentina's economy was relatively isolated, relying heavily on salted meat, wool, leather, and hide industries for foreign exchange earnings and domestic income.

• Post-1880, Argentina experienced rapid economic growth driven by the export of livestock and grain raw materials, alongside significant British and French investments, initiating a fifty-year period of substantial economic expansion and mass European immigration.
• Between 1880 and 1905, Argentina's GDP grew 7.5 times during its most vigorous phase, with an average annual growth rate of about 8%.
• During this period, GDP per capita increased from 35% of the U.S. average to approximately 80%.
• After 1905, growth slowed considerably; by 1941, Argentina's real per capita GDP was roughly half that of the United States.
• From 1890 to 1950, Argentina's per capita income was comparable to Western Europe, although income distribution remained highly unequal.

• A 2009 study by Baten, Pelger, and Twrdek indicated that Argentina's GDP increased after 1870 based on anthropometric data (height and real wages), but heights remained unaffected before 1910, suggesting welfare improvements did not occur during income expansion in that earlier period.
• The Great Depression (1929–1932) caused Argentina's GDP to decline by 25%.
• By the late 1930s, the economy recovered partly through import substitution, and during World War II, it experienced modest growth despite global recession impacts.

• WWII led to reduced import availability and higher export prices, resulting in a US$1.6 billion cumulative trade surplus, with one-third of this surplus blocked as inconvertible deposits in the Bank of England due to the Roca–Runciman Treaty.
• Manufacturing value-added surpassed agriculture for the first time in 1943, employing over 1 million workers by 1947, and reduced the need for imported consumer goods from 40% to 10% by 1950.
• Juan Perón's populist government (1945–1955) nationalized key industries including the Central Bank, railways, and other strategic sectors.
• Inflation became a chronic issue during Perón's era, averaging 26% annually from 1944 to 1974.
• Perón's early 1950s period saw rising GDP per capita until commodity prices dropped and nationalization effects caused stagnation.

• The economy declined further during the National Reorganization Process (1976–1983), with neoliberal policies under José Alfredo Martínez de Hoz increasing debt and failing to curb inflation, which reached 344% in 1983.
• Price and exchange controls were removed, leading to currency devaluation tenfold, disappearance of black markets, but also economic stagnation and a balance of payments crisis.

• From 1975 to 1990, Argentina experienced severe stagflation, hyperinflation in 1989–1990, and a debt crisis culminating in default in 2001, with GDP declining nearly 20% over four years, unemployment reaching 25%, and the peso depreciating 70%.

• Post-2003, Argentina's economy rebounded due to expansionary policies and raw material exports, creating over five million jobs, and restoring social programs and renationalizing key firms such as the postal service, ASA, pension funds, Aerolíneas Argentinas, YPF, and railways.
• From 2002 to 2011, Argentina's GDP nearly doubled, growing at an average of 7.1% annually, with five consecutive years of approximately 9% growth from 2003 to 2007.
• Real wages increased by about 72% from their 2003 lows to 2013.
• The 2008 global financial crisis slowed growth to nearly zero in 2009, but GDP expanded around 9% in both 2010 and 2011.
• From 2012 onward, growth slowed to an average of 1.3% (2012–2014), rising slightly to 2.4% in 2015, due to external shocks, exchange controls, austerity, and inflation.

• Argentina's bond market is based on GDP-linked bonds; in 2005 and 2010, debt restructuring resumed payments on nearly US$100 billion in defaulted bonds, with holdouts led by Paul Singer's NML Capital Limited rejecting swaps and attempting asset seizures.

• By 2012, bondholders who accepted the 2005 exchange received about 90% returns; Argentina settled with holdouts in February 2016 at a cost of US$9.3 billion, with NML receiving US$2.4 billion, a 392% return.

• Argentina considers illegitimate government debt as odious but continues servicing it, costing approximately US$14 billion annually, with bond issues since 2002 averaging less than US$2 billion per year, limiting debt rollover capacity.
• Despite debt issues, Argentina issued a successful US$16.5 billion bond in April 2016, the largest in emerging market history.
• In May 2018, Argentina requested a US$30 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
• In May 2018, inflation was estimated at 25% annually; the central bank raised interest rates to 40% from 27.25%, the highest in the world, as the peso lost 18% of its value since the year's start.
• In 2019, inflation reached 53.8%, the highest in 28 years.

• During the COVID-19 quarantine in April 2020, approximately 143,000 SMEs could not pay salaries and expenses, with about 35,000 considering closure, despite government assistance; some projects estimated 180 total quarantine days and a 5% company failure rate in May.
• In February 2023, inflation surpassed 100% for the first time since the early 1990s.

• By December 2023, Argentina's projected annual inflation rate was 200%, with President Javier Milei implementing policies including a 50% weakening of the peso to 800 per dollar, energy subsidy cuts, public works cancellations, and expense reductions, resulting in a budget surplus for the first time since 2012.

• Milei's policies are characterized by extreme economic reforms, with him describing himself as an anarcho-capitalist; in April 2024, the government announced a plan to cut 15,000 public sector jobs.
• Argentina's 2023 inflation was the highest globally at 211.4%.
• In January 2024, the poverty rate reached 57.4%, the highest since 2004.

• By December 2024, the monthly inflation rate decreased to 2.4%, ending hyperinflation, and the poverty rate fell to 38.9% in the third quarter, with projections of further decline as reforms take effect.
• A December 2024 Gallup poll showed over 50% approval for Milei, with trust in government doubling since 2023, and 53% of Argentinians perceiving an improved standard of living, comparable to 2015.
• Despite improvements, 69% of Argentinians believe it is a bad time to seek employment, and 35% lack sufficient funds for food, though these figures are lower than their 2019 peaks.
• Approval ratings for Milei are higher among the top 20% (59%) than the bottom 20% (39%), but both are higher than ratings for his predecessor, Alberto Fernández.
• In early 2024, Argentina's GDP contracted by 2.1% in Q1 and 1.8% in Q2, but expanded by 3.9% in Q4, driven by a 80.2% rebound in agriculture following a drought.
• The economy is projected to grow 5.5% in 2025 according to BBVA and 3.5% per Goldman Sachs, as inflation stabilizes and investment increases due to liberalization policies.
• Economic activity is recovering after the 2024 recession, with a positive outlook for 2025, expecting inflation to fall below 30%, and growth exceeding 4%.
• The section discusses Argentina's inflation trends, including Year over Year inflation rates, M2 money supply increases, and Month over Month inflation data.

• It presents a comprehensive table of main economic indicators from 1980 to 2023, with IMF staff estimates for 2024–2028, noting that IMF estimates do not reflect actual figures beyond 2023 as they are outdated.
• Inflation below 5% is highlighted in green within the data table.

• In 1980, Argentina's GDP was 172.5 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 6,172.5 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 233.7 billion US dollars, with a GDP per capita of 8,361.2 US dollars.
• The GDP growth rate in 1980 was 0.7%, with an unspecified inflation rate, unemployment at 3.0%, and no available data on government debt.

• In 1981, GDP increased to 178.0 billion US dollars (PPP), with GDP per capita at 6,256.5 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP at 189.8 billion US dollars, with GDP per capita at 6,671.4 US dollars, and a GDP contraction of -5.7%.
• Inflation in 1981 was not specified; unemployment was 5.0%.

• 1982 saw GDP rise to 183.0 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 6,327.2 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 94.3 billion US dollars, with GDP per capita at 3,257.9 US dollars, and a GDP decline of -3.1%.

• In 1983, GDP was 197.3 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 6,725.1 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP at 116.3 billion US dollars, GDP per capita at 3,962.7 US dollars, and a growth rate of 3.7%.
• Inflation rates varied annually, with notable increases in the late 1980s and early 1990s, reaching 10.5% in 1991 and peaking at 25.9% in 2002.
• The data shows fluctuations in unemployment, reaching 25.9% in 2002, and government debt as a percentage of GDP increased significantly, reaching 147.2% in 2002.
• The period from 1992 to 2001 experienced high inflation rates, with inflation at 10.3% in 1992, 6.3% in 1993, and negative inflation in 1995 (-2.8%), indicating deflationary periods.
• Argentina's GDP in 1992 was 297.4 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 8,899.4 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP of 255.8 billion US dollars.
• From 2002 onwards, inflation rates fluctuated dramatically, with a peak of 25.7% in 2017, and inflation exceeding 100% in 2023 at 121.7%.
• Unemployment rates varied, reaching as high as 53.5% in 2019, and decreasing to 7.4% in 2023.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP increased from 25.0% in 1992 to a high of 89.5% projected in 2023, with a slight decrease forecasted for 2024 at 79.9%.
• The GDP in 2010 was 736.8 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 18,063.9 US dollars (PPP), and nominal GDP of 424.7 billion US dollars, with a GDP growth rate of 10.1%.
• The data indicates a significant economic recovery post-2002 crisis, with GDP reaching over 1 trillion US dollars (PPP) by 2017, and continued growth projected through 2028.
• In 2024, IMF estimates project GDP at 1,302.5 billion US dollars (PPP), with GDP per capita at 27,576.3 US dollars (PPP), and a GDP growth rate of 2.8%.
• Inflation in 2024 is estimated at 93.7%, with unemployment at 7.2%, and government debt at 79.9% of GDP.
• The projections for 2025–2028 show continued GDP growth, with GDP reaching approximately 1.57 trillion US dollars (PPP) by 2028, and inflation rates decreasing to around 32.5% in 2028.
• The data highlights persistent inflation challenges, fluctuating unemployment, and rising government debt as key features of Argentina's economic profile over the analyzed period.
• The section discusses Argentina's agriculture sector, highlighting its significance within the national economy and global markets.
• The fertile Pampas region features soy fields, with soybeans constituting approximately 50% of the country's crop production, emphasizing their versatility.
• Argentina's landscape includes vineyards in Mendoza Province, supporting the country's status as the fifth largest wine producer globally.

• Argentina is a major global agricultural producer, ranking among the top producers and exporters of beef, citrus fruits, grapes, honey, maize, sorghum, soybeans, squash, sunflower seeds, wheat, and yerba mate.
• In 2010, agriculture contributed 9% to Argentina's GDP and accounted for about 20% of total exports, with processed food and feed making up an additional third of exports.
• Commercial harvests in 2010 totaled 103 million tons, comprising over 54 million tons of oilseeds (mainly soy and sunflower) and over 46 million tons of cereals (mainly maize, wheat, and sorghum).
• Argentina is the world's largest producer of yerba mate and ranks among the top five globally for soy, maize, sunflower seed, lemon, and pear production.
• The country is also among the top ten producers worldwide of barley, grape, artichoke, tobacco, and cotton, and among the top fifteen for wheat, sugarcane, sorghum, and grapefruit.

• In 2018, Argentina produced 37.7 million tons of soy, ranking third globally behind the US and Brazil; it was the fourth largest maize producer with 43.5 million tons, and the twelfth largest wheat producer with 18.5 million tons.

• Additional 2018 production figures include 1.5 million tons of sorghum (11th largest globally), 1.9 million tons of grapes (10th largest), and 19 million tons of sugarcane, mainly in Tucumán Province, with nearly 2 million tons of sugar derived from the cane.

• Argentina produced 4.1 million tons of barley in 2018, placing it among the top 20 worldwide; sunflower seed production was 2.2 million tons in 2010 and increased to 2.3 million tons in 2018, making it one of the largest producers.

• Other notable 2018 agricultural outputs include 2 million tons of potatoes, almost 2 million tons of lemons, 1.3 million tons of rice, 1 million tons of oranges, 921 thousand tons of peanuts, 813 thousand tons of cotton, 707 thousand tons of onions, 656 thousand tons of tomatoes, 565 thousand tons of pears, 510 thousand tons of apples, and smaller quantities of oats, beans, tangerines, yerba mate, carrots, peaches, cassava, olives, bananas, garlic, grapefruit, and artichokes.

• In livestock, Argentina was the 4th largest global producer of beef in 2019, with 3 million tons, behind the USA, Brazil, and China; it was also the 4th largest honey producer, 10th in wool, 13th in chicken meat, 23rd in pork, 18th in cow's milk, and 14th in chicken eggs.
• Major export commodities include soy and its byproducts (animal feed and vegetable oils), accounting for 25% of total exports, and cereals contributing an additional 10%.
• Cattle-raising is significant but primarily for domestic consumption; beef, leather, and dairy products constitute about 5% of total exports.

• Sheep-raising and wool production are important in Patagonia but have declined by 50% since 1990; biodiesel has become a rapidly growing agro-industrial activity, with exports exceeding US$2 billion in 2011.

• Fruits and vegetables represent 4% of exports, with apples and pears from Río Negro, rice, oranges, and citrus in the northwest and Mesopotamia, grapes and strawberries in Cuyo, and berries in the far south.

• Major crops in specific regions include cotton and tobacco in Gran Chaco, sugarcane and chili peppers in the northwest, olives and garlic in the west, and yerba mate, tomatoes, and peaches for domestic markets.
• Organic farming is expanding, with nearly 3 million hectares (7.5 million acres) under organic cultivation, making Argentina the second-largest globally after Australia.
• Argentina ranks as the world's fifth-largest wine producer, with notable improvements in wine quality and a significant export market; Mendoza is the largest wine region, followed by San Juan.

• Government policies towards agriculture have been contentious, exemplified by the 2008 grain embargo protests over increased export taxes, which largely subsided after the Senate defeated the tax hike on July 16.
• Argentine fisheries produce approximately one million tons annually, focusing on hake (which accounts for 50% of the catch), pollock, squid, and centolla crab.
• The forestry sector has a long history outside the pampas, with roundwood harvests totaling nearly 14 million cubic meters, mainly eucalyptus, pine, and elm for furniture and paper products.
• Fisheries and logging each contribute around 2% to Argentina's exports.

• The Vaca Muerta shale oil field holds an estimated 2.58×10^9 cubic meters (16.2×10^9 barrels) of oil and 8.7×10^12 cubic meters of natural gas, making it potentially the third largest shale oil and gas field in the world.
• Mining and other extractive industries, including gas and petroleum, have experienced growth in Argentina, increasing their contribution from 2% of GDP in 1980 to approximately 4% currently.
• The primary regions for extractive activities are the northwest and San Juan Province.
• Coal mining occurs in Santa Cruz Province.
• The country extracts a variety of metals and minerals, notably borate, copper, lead, magnesium, sulfur, tungsten, uranium, zinc, silver, titanium, and gold.
• Gold production notably increased after 1997 due to the Bajo de la Alumbrera mine located in Catamarca Province, and further investments by Barrick Gold a decade later in San Juan Province.
• Metal ore exports escalated from US$200 million in 1996 to US$1.2 billion in 2004, and surpassed US$3 billion in 2010.
• In 2019, Argentina ranked as the 4th largest producer globally of lithium, the 9th largest for silver, the 17th for gold, and the 7th for boron.
• The country produces approximately 35 million cubic meters (m³) of petroleum and petroleum fuels annually.
• Natural gas production is around 50 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year, contributing to Argentina’s self-sufficiency in these energy resources.
• These energy resources account for about 10% of Argentina’s total exports.
• The most significant oil fields are located in Patagonia and Cuyo regions.

• A network of pipelines transports raw petroleum and natural gas to Bahía Blanca, which is the center of the petrochemical industry, and to the industrial belt encompassing La Plata, Greater Buenos Aires, and Rosario.

• The World Bank annually ranks countries based on total industrial production value; in 2019, Argentina was the 31st most valuable industry globally, with a production value of 57.7 billion dollars, positioned behind Mexico, Brazil, and Venezuela, but ahead of Colombia, Peru, and Chile.

• In 2019, Argentina ranked as the 31st in the world for steel production, 28th for vehicle manufacturing, 22nd for beer production, 4th for soybean oil, and 3rd for sunflower oil, among other industrial products.
• Manufacturing constitutes the largest single sector of Argentina's economy, representing 15% of the country's GDP.
• Approximately 50% of Argentina's industrial exports are agricultural in nature, reflecting the sector's integration with the nation's agriculture.
• Industrial development in Argentina initially focused on food processing and textiles during the early 20th century; over time, production has diversified significantly.

• Leading industrial sectors by production value include: food processing and beverages; motor vehicles and auto parts; refinery products and biodiesel; chemicals and pharmaceuticals; steel and aluminium; industrial and farm machinery; electronics and home appliances.
• The electronics and home appliances sector includes over three million high-value items, such as large appliances, electronics, kitchen appliances, and cellular phones.

• In 2013, Argentina's auto industry produced 791,000 motor vehicles, with 433,000 exported mainly to Brazil, which in turn exported a larger number to Argentina; the domestic auto market reached a record 964,000 new vehicles in 2013.
• Vehicle production peaked in 2013; by 2021, production had decreased to 434,753 vehicles.
• Vehicles remain Argentina's top export to Brazil, generating approximately $3.1 billion in exports in 2021.

• Argentina has a longstanding significant beverage industry, ranking among the top five wine-producing countries worldwide; however, in 2000, beer production surpassed wine, and beer now leads by nearly two billion liters annually over wine.
• Other manufactured goods include glass, cement, plastics, tires, lumber products, textiles, tobacco products, recording and print media, furniture, apparel, and leather.
• As of 2012, Argentina had 314 industrial parks nationwide, a fourfold increase over the previous decade, with nearly half located in the Greater Buenos Aires area.
• Córdoba, Rosario, and Ushuaia are also notable industrial centers; Ushuaia became the leading electronics production hub during the 1980s.
• In 2011, the production of computers, laptops, and servers grew by 160%, reaching nearly 3.4 million units, covering two-thirds of domestic demand.
• Argentina has become a major manufacturer of cell phones, supplying about 80% of all devices sold domestically.
• Farm machinery production, historically dominated by imports, was replaced by domestic manufacturing, which met 60% of demand by 2013.

• The production of high-tech products like cell phones and computers is primarily an assembly industry, relying heavily on imported components and foreign-designed products, with high labor costs limiting sales penetration mainly to Latin America through regional trade agreements.

• Construction permits issued nationwide exceeded 15 million square meters (160 million square feet) in 2013; the construction sector accounts for over 5% of GDP, with two-thirds of activity dedicated to residential buildings.
• Argentina's electricity generation totaled over 133 billion kWh in 2013, primarily sourced from well-developed natural gas and hydroelectric resources.
• Nuclear energy is also significant; Argentina is among the largest producers and exporters of cobalt-60, a radioactive isotope used extensively in cancer therapy, alongside Canada and Russia.
• The service sector is the largest contributor to Argentina's total GDP, accounting for over 60%, making it a critical component of the country's economy.
• Argentina's service sector is highly diversified, encompassing well-developed social, corporate, financial, insurance, real estate, transport, communication services, and tourism industries.
• The telecommunications sector has experienced rapid growth, significantly benefiting the Argentine economy through widespread access to communication services.
• As of the latest available data, 77% of the Argentine population has access to mobile phones, with 95% of these users utilizing smartphones, indicating high smartphone penetration.
• Internet usage in Argentina exceeds 32 million users, representing approximately 75% of the population, with nearly all 14 million broadband accounts in the country.
• Regular telephone services remain robust, with about 9.5 million fixed lines in operation, alongside a strong mail services network.
• Total telecommunications revenues in Argentina surpassed $17.8 billion in 2013, reflecting the sector's substantial economic contribution.
• In 2013, only one in three retail stores accepted online purchases; nonetheless, e-commerce sales reached US$4.5 billion, highlighting growth in digital commerce.
• Despite the growth in services, Argentina's trade in services remained in deficit, with US$15 billion in service exports contrasted against US$19 billion in imports in 2013.
• Business Process Outsourcing (BPO) emerged as the leading Argentine service export, generating US$3 billion in revenue.
• Advertising revenues from contracts abroad were estimated at over US$1.2 billion, indicating a significant international presence in advertising services.
• Tourism has become an increasingly vital sector for Argentina's economy, contributing 4% of direct economic output in 2012, which equates to over US$17 billion.
• Approximately 70% of tourism sector activity by value is generated by domestic tourism within Argentina, emphasizing the importance of internal travel.
• The section notes that the information requires updating as of November 2024, indicating that recent developments or data may not be reflected.
• Argentine banking sector's deposits exceeded US$120 billion in December 2012, reflecting its substantial size.
• The banking system initially developed around public sector banks but is now predominantly dominated by private sector banks.
• Private sector banks account for the majority of the 80 active banking institutions, which operate over 4,000 branches nationwide.
• Private banks hold nearly 60% of total deposits and loans in Argentina.
• The banking sector includes an equal number of foreign-owned banks and locally owned banks operating within the country.
• The largest bank in Argentina by far is the public Banco de la Nación Argentina, which should not be confused with the Central Bank of Argentina.
• Banco de la Nación Argentina accounts for approximately 30% of total deposits and about 20% (a fifth) of the bank’s loan portfolio.
• During the 1990s, Argentina’s financial system underwent significant consolidation and strengthening.
• Between 1991 and 2000, deposits increased from less than US$15 billion to over US$80 billion.
• Outstanding credit in the same period tripled to nearly US$100 billion, with approximately 70% directed to the private sector.
• In the early 2000s, banks primarily lent in US dollars and accepted deposits in Argentine pesos.
• When the peso depreciated significantly in early 2002, many borrowers struggled to meet their obligations, leading to a tripling of delinquencies to about 37%.
• By December 2001, over 20% of deposits had been withdrawn, prompting Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo to impose a near freeze on cash withdrawals.
• The restrictions on withdrawals were lifted a year later, but the public reaction was mixed, with some feeling disappointed that funds were not restored at their full US dollar value.
• The collapse of Velox Bank resulted in client losses of up to US$800 million due to fraud.
• Credit in Argentina remains relatively tight; lending has been increasing at approximately 40% annually since 2004.
• Delinquency rates have decreased to less than 2%.
• Despite growth, credit outstanding to the private sector in real terms is slightly below its peak in 1998, and it represents around 18% of GDP, which is low by international standards.
• The prime interest rate, which was around 10% in the 1990s, surged to 67% in 2002 during the financial crisis.

• The prime rate quickly normalized after 2002 but has been affected again by inflation and global instability, reaching over 20% for much of 2009 and remaining around 17% since the first half of 2010.
• Due to economic instability, Argentines have historically held more deposits overseas than domestically, with an estimated US$173 billion in overseas accounts and investments in 2012.
• The overseas holdings exceeded the domestic monetary base (M3) by nearly US$10 billion in 2012.

• According to the World Economic Forum's 2017 Travel & Tourism Competitiveness Report, tourism in Argentina generated over US$22 billion, representing 3.9% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• The tourism industry employed more than 671,000 people, accounting for approximately 3.7% of the total workforce in Argentina.
• Foreign tourism contributed US$5.3 billion to the economy, making it the third largest source of foreign exchange for Argentina in 2004.

• In 2017, approximately 5.7 million foreign visitors arrived in Argentina, reflecting a doubling of international visitors since 2002 despite the country's currency, the peso, experiencing relative appreciation.
• Argentine nationals, who have historically been active domestic travelers, accounted for over 80% of total tourism activity within the country.
• International tourism to Argentina has experienced healthy growth, nearly doubling since 2001, after being stagnant for over two decades.
• Domestic travel in Argentina increased strongly in recent years, with visitors attracted by the country's affordability, exceptional diversity, and safety.
• Foreign tourism, both inbound and outbound, is increasing; in 2013, INDEC recorded 5.2 million foreign tourist arrivals and 6.7 million departures.

• Of the 2013 foreign arrivals, 32% came from Brazil, 19% from Europe, 10% from the United States and Canada, 10% from Chile, 24% from the rest of the Western Hemisphere, and 5% from the rest of the world.
• Approximately 48% of foreign visitors arrived by commercial flight, 40% by motor travel (primarily from neighboring Brazil), and 12% by sea.
• Cruise liner arrivals are the fastest-growing segment of foreign tourism in Argentina; in 2013, a total of 160 cruise liners carrying 510,000 passengers arrived at the Port of Buenos Aires.
• The number of cruise liner arrivals increased eightfold over a decade, highlighting significant growth in cruise tourism to Argentina.

• The supply sector's contribution to Argentina's GDP, measured at current prices, is categorized into various industries with data spanning from 1993 to 2013, divided into four periods: 1993–2001, 2002–2005, 2006–2009, and 2010–2013.
• Agriculture, forestry, and fishing accounted for 5.4% of GDP in 1993–2001, increased to 10.3% during 2002–2005, then decreased to 7.3% in both 2006–2009 and 2010–2013.
• The mining sector contributed 2.0% of GDP in 1993–2001, rose significantly to 5.9% in 2002–2005, slightly decreased to 4.8% in 2006–2009, and further declined to 4.2% in 2010–2013.
• Manufacturing represented 18.5% of GDP in 1993–2001, increased to 23.2% during 2002–2005, then decreased to 19.8% in 2006–2009, and further declined to 16.8% in 2010–2013.
• Public utilities contributed 2.2% of GDP in 1993–2001, decreased to 1.7% in 2002–2005, then increased to 2.3% in 2006–2009, and further to 3.1% in 2010–2013.
• Construction's share was 5.5% in 1993–2001, decreased to 3.9% during 2002–2005, increased to 6.2% in 2006–2009, and slightly decreased to 5.6% in 2010–2013.
• Commerce and tourism contributed 17.3% of GDP in 1993–2001, decreased to 14.0% in 2002–2005, then increased to 15.6% in 2006–2009, and decreased again to 14.4% in 2010–2013.
• Transport and communications accounted for 8.3% in 1993–2001, slightly increased to 8.7% during 2002–2005, then decreased to 7.3% in 2006–2009, and further to 6.7% in 2010–2013.
• Financial services contributed 4.2% of GDP in 1993–2001, marginally increased to 4.4% in 2002–2005, then decreased to 3.2% in 2006–2009, and slightly increased to 3.4% in 2010–2013.
• Real estate and business services represented 16.5% of GDP in 1993–2001, decreased to 11.7% during 2002–2005, then increased to 13.7% in 2006–2009, and decreased again to 12.9% in 2010–2013.
• Public administration and defense accounted for 6.3% in 1993–2001, decreased to 5.4% in 2002–2005, slightly increased to 5.6% in 2006–2009, and significantly increased to 7.4% in 2010–2013.
• Health and education services made up 8.4% of GDP in 1993–2001, decreased to 6.9% in 2002–2005, then increased substantially to 8.9% in 2006–2009, and further to 11.9% in 2010–2013.
• Personal and other services contributed 5.4% in 1993–2001, decreased to 3.9% in 2002–2005, then increased to 5.3% in 2006–2009, and further to 6.3% in 2010–2013.
• The total sum of all sectors consistently equals 100.0% across all periods, reflecting the proportional distribution of GDP by value added in each timeframe.
• A note indicates that a new methodology was adopted at some point, making data not strictly comparable to earlier figures.
• In 2013, Argentina's electricity generation totaled 133.3 billion kilowatt-hours (kWh), establishing it as the third largest power market in Latin America.

• The Argentine electricity sector primarily relies on centralized generation methods, with natural gas accounting for 51% of electricity production, hydroelectricity for 28%, and oil-fired generation for 12%.
• The Vaca Muerta oil field and other regions in Argentina are estimated to contain the world's third-largest resources of unconventional shale gas and tight oil.
• In 2017, Argentina was the 18th largest producer of natural gas globally and the largest producer in Latin America.
• In 2020, Argentina produced 70,000 cubic meters (m³) of oil per day, equivalent to approximately 440,300 barrels (bbl) per day, ranking as the 28th largest oil producer worldwide.
• Despite possessing significant untapped wind and solar energy potential, these renewable sources are minimally exploited; wind energy is the fastest-growing among new renewables.
• Since 1994, Argentina has developed fifteen wind farms, making it the only country in Latin America to produce wind turbines domestically.
• The installed wind capacity was 55 MW in 2010, with plans to increase by 895 MW following the completion of new wind farms initiated that year.
• Solar power capacity is targeted to expand from 6 MW to 300 MW, and total renewable energy capacity from 625 MW to 3,000 MW.
• By the end of 2021, Argentina ranked 21st globally in installed hydroelectric capacity at 11.3 GW, 26th in wind energy with 3.2 GW, and 43rd in solar energy with 1.0 GW.

• The country is actively commissioning large centralized energy generation and transmission projects, primarily financed by government trust funds; private sector initiatives are limited due to economic recovery challenges post-crisis.
• The first nuclear reactor in Argentina was inaugurated in 1974; by 2015, nuclear power contributed approximately 5% to the country's total energy output.
• The Argentine electricity sector was restructured in the early 1990s into separate segments: generation, transmission, and distribution.
• Electricity generation occurs in a competitive and largely liberalized market, with private utilities owning about 75% of generation capacity.
• Conversely, the transmission and distribution sectors are highly regulated and less competitive compared to generation.
• Argentina's transport infrastructure is relatively advanced and maintains a higher standard compared to the rest of Latin America.

• The country has over 230,000 km (144,000 mi) of roads, excluding private rural roads, with 72,000 km (45,000 mi) paved and 2,800 km (1,700 mi) designated as expressways, many of which are privatized tollways.
• Multilane expressways have tripled in length over the past decade, now connecting several major cities, with additional expressways under construction.

• Despite expansion, expressways are currently inadequate for local traffic demands, as over 12 million motor vehicles were registered nationally as of 2012, representing the highest proportion in the region.
• The railway network extends approximately 37,856 km (23,523 mi), down from a peak of 47,000 km (29,204 mi), reflecting decades of decline and inadequate maintenance.
• Most intercity passenger rail services ceased in 1992 following privatization and the breakup of the state rail company, leading to thousands of kilometers falling into disuse.
• Outside Greater Buenos Aires, most operational rail lines are freight-oriented, transporting around 23 million tons annually.
• The metropolitan rail system in Buenos Aires, including commuter lines and the Buenos Aires Underground, remains highly in demand due to easy access to the underground network.
• The commuter rail network in Buenos Aires spans 833 km (518 mi) and carries approximately 1.4 million passengers daily.
• In April 2015, the Argentine Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation to re-create Ferrocarriles Argentinos as Nuevos Ferrocarriles Argentinos, effectively re-nationalizing the railways.

• Prior to re-nationalization, the government invested significantly in the railways, purchasing new rolling stock, reopening lines closed under privatization, and re-nationalizing companies such as Belgrano Cargas.

• Reopened services include the General Roca Railway to Mar del Plata, the Tren a las Nubes tourist train, and the General Mitre Railway from Buenos Aires to Córdoba; a new service is the Posadas-Encarnación International Train.

• The Buenos Aires Underground, inaugurated in 1913, was the first underground system in Latin America, the Spanish-speaking world, and the Southern Hemisphere, with 60 km (37 mi) of track carrying about one million passengers daily.
• Argentina has approximately 11,000 km (6,835 mi) of navigable waterways, which transport more cargo than the freight railways.
• The country’s waterways include an extensive network of canals and natural rivers such as Río de la Plata, Paraná, Uruguay, Río Negro, and Paraguay.
• The Port of Buenos Aires, opened in 1925, is the largest port in Argentina, handling 11 million tons of freight and transporting 1.8 million passengers in 2013.
• Aerolíneas Argentinas is the primary airline, providing extensive domestic and international flights.
• LADE, a military-run commercial airline, operates extensive domestic services.
• In 2013, Argentina’s 33 airports handled a total of 25.8 million air passengers, with domestic flights accounting for over 14.5 million.
• The two busiest airports, Jorge Newbery and Ministro Pistarini International Airport, each handled around 9 million flights in 2013.
• In 2022, Argentina ranked as the 44th largest exporter globally in merchandise exports, with a total of US$88 billion, representing 0.4% of the world's total merchandise exports.
• Argentine exports are relatively diversified; agricultural raw materials constitute over 20% of total exports, but including processed foods, agricultural goods account for over 50% of exports.
• Soy products, including soybeans and vegetable oil, alone make up nearly one quarter (25%) of Argentina's total exports.
• Cereals, primarily maize and wheat, which were Argentina's leading exports during much of the twentieth century, now constitute less than 10% of total exports.

• Industrial goods currently represent over one-third (more than 33%) of Argentine exports; the leading industrial export is motor vehicles and auto parts, accounting for over 12% of total merchandise exports.
• Other significant industrial exports include chemicals, steel, aluminum, machinery, and plastics.
• Historically, Argentina has maintained a trade deficit in manufactured goods; despite an overall trade surplus, the manufacturing trade deficit exceeded US$30 billion in 2011.

• In response, the Argentine government extended the system of non-automatic import licensing in 2011 and enacted regulations for the auto sector, establishing a model where a company's future imports are determined by their exports, though not necessarily within the same category.

• Argentina was a net energy importer until 1987; starting in the early 1990s, fuel exports increased rapidly and now account for about one-eighth (12.5%) of total exports, with refined fuels comprising roughly half of that share.
• Exports of crude petroleum and natural gas have been around US$3 billion annually in recent years.

• Due to rapidly growing domestic energy demand and a gradual decline in oil production, Argentina experienced a US$3 billion energy trade deficit in 2011 (the first in 17 years) and a US$6 billion deficit in 2013.

• Argentine imports are predominantly focused on industrial and technological supplies, machinery, and parts, averaging US$50 billion since 2011, which accounts for approximately two-thirds (66.7%) of total imports.
• Consumer goods, including motor vehicles, constitute the remaining significant portion of imports.
• Trade in services has historically been in deficit; in 2013, the service trade deficit widened to over US$4 billion, with record service imports totaling US$19 billion.
• Argentina's chronic current account deficit was reversed during the 2002 economic crisis; from 2002 to 2009, the country experienced an average current account surplus of US$7 billion.
• After 2009, the current account surplus narrowed significantly and has been slightly negative since 2011.
• In 2023, Argentina's goods exports totaled $66.8 billion US dollars, while imports reached $69.8 billion US dollars, resulting in a net trade deficit of $2.9 billion US dollars.
• In 2020, Argentina's goods exports were valued at $55.0 billion US dollars, with imports amounting to $40.3 billion US dollars, leading to a net trade surplus of $14.6 billion US dollars.
• In 2015, the country exported goods worth $56.8 billion US dollars and imported goods valued at $57.6 billion US dollars, resulting in a slight net trade deficit of $0.8 billion US dollars.
• In 2010, Argentina's goods exports increased to $68.3 billion US dollars, with imports at $54.2 billion US dollars, producing a net trade surplus of $14.2 billion US dollars.
• In 2000, exports were $26.3 billion US dollars, and imports were $23.9 billion US dollars, resulting in a net trade surplus of $2.5 billion US dollars.
• In 1990, Argentina exported goods worth $12.4 billion US dollars and imported goods worth $3.7 billion US dollars, yielding a net trade surplus of $8.6 billion US dollars.
• In 1980, exports totaled $8.0 billion US dollars, while imports were higher at $9.4 billion US dollars, leading to a net trade deficit of $1.4 billion US dollars.

• In 2022, Argentina's largest trading partner by total trade value was Brazil, with a total trade volume of 28.70 billion USD, comprising imports worth 16.03 billion USD and exports valued at 12.67 billion USD, resulting in a trade balance of -3.36 billion USD, indicating a trade deficit with Brazil.

• China ranked as Argentina’s second-largest trading partner in 2022, with a total trade value of 25.53 billion USD; imports from China amounted to 17.51 billion USD, while exports to China were 8.02 billion USD, leading to a significant trade deficit of -9.49 billion USD.

• The United States was Argentina’s third-largest trading partner in 2022, with total trade valued at 17.01 billion USD; imports from the U.S. totaled 10.33 billion USD, and exports to the U.S. were 6.68 billion USD, resulting in a trade deficit of -3.65 billion USD.

• India ranked as a notable trading partner with a total trade volume of 6.40 billion USD; Argentina’s imports from India were 1.85 billion USD, while exports to India reached 4.55 billion USD, producing a trade surplus of 2.70 billion USD.

• Chile was another significant partner, with total trade valued at 5.71 billion USD; imports from Chile were 0.778 billion USD, and exports to Chile were 4.94 billion USD, resulting in a substantial trade surplus of 4.16 billion USD.

• Vietnam’s trade with Argentina in 2022 totaled 4.47 billion USD; imports from Vietnam were 1.24 billion USD, and exports to Vietnam were 3.23 billion USD, yielding a trade surplus of 1.99 billion USD.

• The Netherlands had a total trade volume of 4.46 billion USD with Argentina; imports from the Netherlands were 0.886 billion USD, and exports to the Netherlands were 3.57 billion USD, resulting in a trade surplus of 2.68 billion USD.

• Germany’s trade with Argentina was valued at 3.60 billion USD; imports from Germany amounted to 2.72 billion USD, while exports to Germany were 0.884 billion USD, leading to a trade deficit of -1.83 billion USD.
• Paraguay’s trade totaled 3.28 billion USD; imports from Paraguay were 1.96 billion USD, and exports to Paraguay were 1.32 billion USD, resulting in a trade deficit of -0.635 billion USD.
• Spain’s trade with Argentina was valued at 2.99 billion USD; imports from Spain were 1.26 billion USD, and exports to Spain were 1.73 billion USD, resulting in a trade surplus of 0.473 billion USD.
• Foreign direct investment (FDI) in Argentina is nearly evenly distributed among three sectors: manufacturing (36%), natural resources (34%), and services (30%).
• Within manufacturing, the leading sectors attracting FDI are the chemical and plastics sector (10%) and the automotive sector (6%).
• In natural resources, the primary sectors receiving FDI are oil and gas (22%) and mining (5%).
• The services sector attracting FDI includes telecommunications (6%), finance (5%), and retail trade (4%).
• Spain was the leading source of foreign direct investment in Argentina, contributing US$22 billion, which accounted for 28% of total FDI in 2009.
• The United States was the second-largest source of FDI, with US$13 billion, representing 17% of total FDI in 2009.
• By 2011, China had become the third-largest source of FDI in Argentina.
• Other significant sources of foreign investment include the Netherlands, Brazil, Chile, and Canada.
• In 2012, foreign nationals held approximately US$112 billion in direct investment in Argentina.

• Several bilateral agreements facilitate U.S. private investment in Argentina, including an agreement with the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) and an active program with the U.S. Export-Import Bank.

• The 1994 U.S.–Argentina Bilateral Investment Treaty grants U.S. investors national treatment in all sectors except shipbuilding, fishing, nuclear-power generation, and uranium production, and it provides for international arbitration of investment disputes.
• FDI in Argentina averaged US$5.7 billion annually from 1992 to 1998.
• FDI reached US$24 billion in 1999, largely due to the purchase of 98% of YPF stock by Repsol.
• During the economic crisis, FDI fell to US$1.6 billion in 2003.
• FDI then increased to US$8 billion in 2008, but the global crisis caused a decline to US$4 billion in 2009.
• FDI recovered to US$6.2 billion in 2010 and further increased to US$8.7 billion in 2011.
• In the first half of 2012, FDI inflows rose by a further 42%.

• Despite recovery, FDI volume remained below the regional average as a percentage of GDP, partly due to policies under the Kirchner Administration and difficulties in enforcing contractual obligations.
• The composition of foreign investment shifted after 2000; over half of FDI during the 1990s consisted of privatizations and mergers and acquisitions.
• Post-2000, Argentina’s FDI became the most technologically oriented in the region, with 51% of FDI in medium and high-tech sectors, compared to 36% in Brazil and only 3% in Chile.
• The Argentine economy experienced a strong recovery following the 2001–02 financial crisis, reaching the 21st largest economy in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms in 2011.
• In 2011, Argentina's per capita income on a PPP basis was the highest in Latin America.
• A lobbying group representing US creditors, who refused to accept Argentina's debt-swap programs, has campaigned for Argentina's expulsion from the G20.
• These holdouts include numerous vulture funds that rejected the 2005 debt offer and instead pursued legal actions to obtain higher returns on their defaulted bonds.
• Disputes with holdout creditors resulted in liens against Argentine central bank accounts in New York and indirectly led to reduced access to international credit markets for Argentina.

• The government, under President Mauricio Macri, announced plans to seek a new $30 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in May 2018 to prevent another economic collapse similar to that of 2001.
• The May 2018 IMF loan announcement coincided with high inflation and falling interest rates in Argentina.
• Following 25 years of economic boom and bust cycles, Argentina's economy doubled in size from 2002 to 2013.
• Official statistics indicated a decline in income poverty from 54% in 2002 to 5% in 2013; however, an alternative measurement by CONICET showed a reduction to 15.4%.
• Poverty measured by living conditions decreased from 17.7% in the 2001 Census to 12.5% in the 2010 Census, indicating a slower pace of improvement.
• Argentina's unemployment rate declined from 25% in 2002 to approximately 7% since 2011, driven by increased global demand for Argentine raw materials and robust domestic growth.

• Due to ongoing disputes with holdout bondholders, the Argentine government has become cautious about sending assets abroad, such as the presidential plane or artworks, fearing they might be impounded by courts influenced by holdouts.
• The government has faced accusations of manipulating economic statistics.

• The official Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation figures in Argentina are released monthly by the National Institute of Statistics and Censuses (INDEC) and have been a subject of political controversy from 2007 through 2015.
• Leading union leaders, even within the general populace, often disregard the official inflation data when negotiating pay raises, indicating widespread distrust of the official figures.
• Private-sector estimates for inflation in 2010 suggest a rate of approximately 25%, significantly higher than the official reported rate of 10.9% for the same year.
• Inflation estimates from various provinces within Argentina also tend to be higher than the national government’s official figures, highlighting regional discrepancies.

• The Argentine government has defended the validity of its official CPI data but has sought assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to develop a new, nationwide inflation index to replace the existing one.

• The official CPI is calculated based on a basket of 520 products; however, controversy exists because these products are not explicitly specified, raising questions about how many are subject to price caps and subsidies.
• Economic analysts who publish inflation estimates that conflict with official statistics have faced prosecution, reflecting the contentious nature of inflation measurement in Argentina.

• The government enforces a fine of up to 500,000 pesos on individuals or entities providing "fraudulent inflation figures," indicating strict penalties for dissenting or unofficial inflation estimates.

• Starting in 2015, the Argentine government resumed soliciting competitive bids from the private sector to provide a weekly independent inflation index, aiming to introduce more transparency and credibility into inflation measurement.
• Argentina's money supply has been increasing year over year, with daily data points indicating persistent expansion.
• High inflation has been a longstanding weakness of the Argentine economy, persisting for decades.
• Unofficial estimates suggest inflation has been around 25% annually since 2008, despite official statistics reporting less than half that figure.
• The inflation levels since 2008 are the highest since the 2002 devaluation of the peso.

• In 2010, a committee was established in the Argentine Chamber of Deputies by opposition Deputies Patricia Bullrich, Ricardo Gil Lavedra, and others to publish an alternative inflation index based on private estimates.

• Food price increases, especially for beef, began to outpace wage growth in 2010, leading Argentines to reduce beef consumption per capita from 69 kg (152 lb) to 57 kg (125 lb) annually and increasing consumption of other meats.
• Consumer inflation expectations reached 28 to 30% in late 2010, prompting the national mint to purchase banknotes of its highest denomination (100 pesos) from Brazil to meet demand.
• During 2011, the central bank injected at least 1 billion pesos into the economy through such purchases.
• As of June 2015, the Argentine government reported inflation at 15.3%, roughly half of some independent estimates; IMF estimates placed inflation at approximately 18.6% in 2015.
• Following a sharp devaluation enacted by President Mauricio Macri on 17 December 2015, inflation surged during the first half of 2016, reaching 42% according to the Finance Ministry.
• Supermarkets in Argentina adopted electronic price tags to enable quicker price updates in response to inflation.
• In Q2 2019, reports indicated that the economy was deteriorating, with rising inflation and currency depreciation, despite receiving one of the largest IMF financial support programs ever.
• In 2019, poverty increased to 32% from 26% the previous year.
• In August 2019, the government imposed restrictions on foreign currency purchases to stabilize the economy.
• Inflation rose to 52.3% in February 2022 from 50.7% the previous month, marking the steepest monthly increase since September 2021.

• The interest rate was increased to 69.5% in August 2022 as inflation reached a 20-year high of 70%, driven by the 2021–2022 inflation surge, with forecasts predicting over 90% inflation by year's end.
• Inflation exceeded 100% in February 2023 for the first time since 1991.
• On October 12, 2023, Argentina's central bank increased the benchmark interest rate from 118% to 133%, following worse-than-expected inflation data (12.7% monthly, 138% annually).
• Argentine workers protested inflation by holding funerals to mourn the "death of (their) wages," highlighting the economic hardship caused by rising prices.
• Photographer Irina Werning described inflation as destroying savings, impeding planning, and discouraging investment, reflecting widespread discontent.
• After Javier Milei's landslide victory in the October 2023 presidential elections, significant efforts were made to curb inflation, with notable success.
• In January 2022, monthly inflation increased from 2.4% to a peak of 25% just before Milei's inauguration.
• Upon taking office, Milei devalued the peso by 50% to narrow the gap between the official and market exchange rates; within a year, he reduced monthly inflation to 2.4%.

• Due to the persistent exchange rate gap, Milei implemented a policy of a 2% monthly devaluation of the peso, which contributed to inflation; the actual, effective monetary inflation rate was only 0.4%.
• In 2024, the Argentine Peso appreciated by 44.2% against the US dollar, outperforming all other currencies, with the second-best being the Turkish Lira, which gained 21.2%.
• The peso's strengthening doubled average wages in dollar terms to $990, aiming to stabilize an economy on the brink of hyperinflation.
• Argentina exhibits a moderate to low level of income inequality relative to other Latin American countries, with a Gini coefficient of approximately 0.407 in 2022.

• The social disparity is most pronounced in the suburbs of Buenos Aires, where beneficiaries of the economic rebound tend to live in gated communities, while many impoverished residents reside in slums known as villas miserias.
• In the mid-1970s, the wealthiest 10% of Argentina's population earned an income 12 times greater than that of the poorest 10%.
• By the mid-1990s, this income ratio increased to 18 times, reflecting growing inequality.
• During the peak of the economic crisis in 2002, the income of the richest 10% was 43 times that of the poorest 10%.
• Post-2002 economic recovery saw a reduction in income disparity, with the ratio decreasing to 26 times by 2006 and further to 16 times by the end of 2010.
• In 2002, the wealthiest 10% captured 40% of all income, whereas the poorest 10% received only 1.1%.
• By 2010, the richest 10%'s share of income declined to 29%, while the poorest 10%'s share increased slightly to 1.8%.
• Argentina's inequality-adjusted human development index (IHDI) stands at 0.729, which is higher than Brazil's 0.578 but slightly below Chile's 0.709.
• The 2010 Census indicated that poverty based on living conditions still affected 1 in 8 inhabitants.
• The official household survey in 2013 reported an income poverty rate of 4.7%, based on a threshold of US$100 per person per month (net).
• The National Research Council estimated that in 2010, income poverty affected 22.6% of the population.
• Private consulting firms estimated that around 21% of the population fell below the income poverty line in 2011.
• The World Bank estimated that in 2013, 3.6% of Argentinians subsisted on less than US$3.10 per person per day.
